here the internet's busiest music nerd
and it's time for a review of the new
lucy dacus record
home video this is the new and third
album of rising indie star as well as
singer songwriter
lucy dakis like many in the scene she
went mostly silent during the pandemic
year
which is unfortunate because i'm
guessing there were plans to release
this project
sooner rather than later given that she
spent 2019
teasing us with a load of singles that
had cheekily similar
cover art but anyway we started getting
tastes of this record
this past spring with a curious run of
singles starting with the skeletal and
semi-ambient thumbs
which features a soothing sound paired
with some
harrowing violent fantasies these
fantasies intruding on daikis's thoughts
and storytelling
as she essentially details her
experience as being
a third wheel in a situation where she
with someone who she
appears to care about very much is
meeting with their estranged father
trying to be supportive of this person
who she can tell very obviously in this
moment
is going through a tough time trying to
process and just exist
in in this attempt at reconnecting now
again
instrumentally this track is incredibly
bare but the storytelling as well as the
forlorn vocals are enough to get the
emotional message across
this is contrasted pretty strongly with
the opening track the
pumping hot and heavy that features a
visceral mid-paced indie rock backing
beat i love the way the groove of this
track
slowly builds momentum along with the
shimmering pianos and guitars too
there's kind of a classic elliott
smith-esque vocal overdub on dakis's
singing as well the lyrics are
beautifully written and sharply metered
they say so much and yet uh every word
that deicus is singing just rolls off
the tongue
so fluidly each bar on this track hits
like a sentimental
nostalgic rush of past triumphs and
traumas overall it's a righteous opener
that gives this record a golden start
then brando was another great teaser to
this record which also showcased
dakis's knack for descriptive lyricism
and storytelling there's a hilarious and
chaotic energy to the relationship being
described on this track
as well as the dialogue it's like i'm
reading an ingenious rom-com script the
instrumentation on the track
unfolds in a nuanced cinematic way too
now vbs is maybe the weakest of all the
singles due to its groggy
boilerplate indie folk backing beat but
at least the way slayer gets referenced
is hilarious
and the lyrics are pretty compelling on
this one too with dacus describing what
sounds like an experience at a christian
bible camp
which i think is clear given the title
and the references to preachers as well
as praising god
while also taking time to take special
note of the debauchery and
flawed characters in between and i say
characters because i mean characters
given the title of this project as home
video many of the tracks here run like
short films with an incredible attention
to detail as well as witty dialogue that
has me hanging on every word
and when i dug further into the record i
found many of the deep cuts to be just
as gratifying as the singles
and a lot of these tracks seem to center
around formative moments during daix's
youth too
whether that's on cartwheel which seems
to be about being at an age where your
friends are getting into boys and dating
and
not quite being ready to make that jump
as well and feeling almost betrayed or
left behind
when other people who you know or care
about are making that transition
and i think daca says a grown woman does
a great job of kind of
portraying that fear and irrationality
that a child might
be dealing with in that moment there's
also going going gone which is a gentle
folky cute ballad with some very bare
guitars and
gorgeous background vocals and harmonies
the lyrics smartly describe a cycle of
first loves eventually leading to
protective parents who are
dreading the day that their kids start
dating and falling in love and getting
their hearts broken
there's also partner in crime which is a
curious change of pace with its booming
beats and
kind of auto-tune affected lead vocals
often these electronic leaning indie
tracks don't go over very well and i

the sound and pacing on this track is

we also have the heart wrenching please

existence dakis's
singing and her lyricism a feature

then triple dog dare is a fantastic

to
in a very meta way tie this album and

with mentions of after all this there's
still a lot to figure out
uh what was the end of the movie about
have i overstayed my welcome at one

pretty gigantic and despite the fact

lyrically i think uh dakis ties this

really kind of makes the whole thing

overall home video i thought it was a

there were some points where
